title.narrative: Advancing Women’s Engagement: Strengthening Opportunities to Mobilize for Equality (AWESOME)

description.narrative: A 5 year advocacy programme to support women’s movements in Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda to be strengthened, less fragmented and more representative of diverse groups of women, including women with disabilities. These stronger women’s movements will contribute to strong women leaders at all levels, and the prevention and elimination of sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) against women and girls.

title.narrative: An increase in gender sensitive and disability inclusive coverage and reporting in the media
Number of media spots that promote women’s (including WwDs) rights related to SGBV

description.narrative: Society 2.09: # and type of media pieces which promote women's rights and ending SGBV

comment.narrative: Our baseline survey result revealed that the main sources of information on workplace SGBV in the area are TV (47.4%) and Radio (22.2%). Media plays a great role in informing the wider community and awareness creation, for example, currently there is a popular program on TV and weekly radio program “from police files” in which crime cases are dramatically presented and has wider audience. Our survey also found that 48% of respondents do not received any information related to SGBV and Gender equality promotion, so there is need for significant awareness raising to create space for CSO demands around SGBV and women's rights. Factory managers reported that there is no gender equally promotion media outlet in their respective factories except they heard from mainstreaming media. The key informant interviews explained the importance of community-led awareness raising, which we are addressing through other AWESOME indicators.

"In the Ethiopian context, SWDA does not control the media. Hence, we will approach this indicator in two directions. 1. SWDA will prepare media pieces to be published on news, as we have already got invitation from the Ethiopian Press Afan Oromo division to sign a contract and use page weekly for the entire year. Hence, we are reviewing it. 2. We can invite WROs to publish media pieces on selected topics pertaining to the proposal. 3. We will also count the media pieces produced by media personnel after the training.
For the changes we are seeking, we want to see these demands raised through media spaces: i. Community awareness on SGBV is enhanced and GBV incidents reduced ii. Law enforcement in action iii. GBV case reporting become culture of the community iv. Stronger women movement in place v. Platforms are created to enhance networks among elected and women in the leadership position vi. 50% ratio for women in the leadership position at the lower administration exercised "

title.narrative: Increased collective advocacy efforts by women's rights organisation (WRO) actors for policy change and legal reform, national and regional level
Number of influencing spaces attended or facilitated related to SGBV and participation

description.narrative: Formal institutions 3.6: # public debates and national events held

comment.narrative:
"According to the survey result, Kii and FGD discussants pointed that different organizations have organized different events pertaining to the subject matter.
Various discussion platforms were conducted with different community groups, elected women, representatives of different sector offices on GBV and women participation. The planned and implemented activities were to support mobilization, networking and enhance women’s participation. The accomplished activities have created a safe space for different community groups to discuss freely in Year 1."

The public debates and national events focused on the core issue of SGBVs and increasing women’s participation in leadership positions at all level. Online TV discussion organized on Oromia regional television with key Oromia Region offices and the case of the Sulfuric Acid victim who was released after 5 years from 25 years imprisonment created a big debate and became subject for investigation and action. The policy gap will be clearly identified and reported to the policy makers through the government representatives (Women leaders and regional councils). These all events and promotional roles will highly influence the behavioural change among the communities.

title.narrative: An increase in the number and diversity of women supported with training, awareness raising, and networking

Number of women supported with training, awareness raising, and networking. (Note - we are tracking both the number of women supported with capacity, and the smaller number of those who then go onto actively engage in the women's movement (below).

description.narrative: Self 1.1 # of women actively participating in the women’s movement like women’s consultation meetings, rallies, political election campaigns to voice their concerns

comment.narrative:
"Quantitative: In Sebeta: 0 women. In Bishoftu: Many women, identified 28 for now. In Modjo: There are three women's groups and also women activists.
Qualitative: as per KII and FGD participants, there are no vibrant women standing to respond to women's right and pressing community problems. .

1,340 women participate in AWESOME activities. The activities are planned to create safe space and discussion platforms to enhance self-awareness, build confidence and build network among them. Hence the desired future capacity is working on movement building to have collective voice to influence and challenge patriarchal system

985 women participate in AWESOME activities. The activities are planned to create safe space and discussion platforms to enhance self-awareness, build confidence and build network among them. Hence the desired future capacity is working on movement building to have collective voice to influence and challenge patriarchal system.

Hence the desired future capacity is working on movement building to have collective voice to influence and challenge patriarchal system
